reviewText: I just finished watching the show from the 80's.  I've always considered myself a big ZZ Top fan.  As I recall, I saw them back in the 70's at the Tarrant County Convention Center in Ft. Worth and then again in Austin at the First Annual Rompin' Stompin' Barn Dance and Bar-B-Que (I forget what year that was).  I saw them again in the late 90's in St. Louis.  I just don't recall ever seeing Billy Gibbons this hopped up on so much 'natural' energy!  :-D  I wish I had seen them more back then!Edit: I just wanted to add, that in my opinion, their studio work is much better than this live stuff for the great sound nuances of the guitar riffs, but this is still a heck of an entertaining DVD.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is ZZ Top back in 1980, doing what the do best, Rock Your World. This is them when they were a bit younger and they just threw caution to the wind. They play their asses off and give you a show to boot. Just buy it, anything ZZ Top is worth the money and time. When they're gone, there is going to a big hole no one will be able to fill, just SRV, he's been gone how long, who's out there as good that just makes you step back and say Damn? Same here with ZZ Top.Amen
Title: N/A

reviewText: Disc 1 of this set is a real jewel. An ample concert from 1980, plenty of classic pre-synthesizer ZZ Top. This disc is worth the price of admission and it's a good thing, since Disc 2 is such a waste.If the 2008 concert footage was presented without all the "fancy" edits (road clips, etc.) it would be great. As is, though, it's an exercise in frustration just to try watching it.I suppose we should just be glad they didn't butcher Disc One. That would've been a tragedy.If you're a Top fan, get it for the 1980 disc. It's a real treat.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I really loved ZZ Top's last DVD release "Live From Texas", and now I like this release even more. You get a 22 song concert, that was filmed in Essen, Germany for the Rockpalast,(Rock Palace) Show, during 1980. Then you get another disc, which includes 11 song performances from their 2008 world tours. These performances are all previously unreleased. There is NO duplication of the "Live From Texas" DVD.The line-up is the same as its always been: Billy Gibbons on lead vocals & guitar, Dusty Hill on some lead vocals & bass guitar, and Frank Beard on drums.Disc One: The 1980 Rockpalast Concert: (Song Set)1.I Thank You2.Waitin' for the Bus3.Jesus just left Chicago4.Precious and Grace5.I'm Bad, I'm Nationwide6.Manic Mechanic7.Lowdown in the Street8.Heard it on the X9.Fool For Your Stockings10.Nasty Dogs & Funky Kings11.El Diablo12.Cheap Sunglasses13.Arrested for Driving While Blind14.Beer Drinkers & Hell Raisers15.La Grange16.She Loves My Automobile17.Hi Fi Mama18.Dust My Broom19.Jailhouse Rock20.Tush21.Tube Snake Boogie22.Just Got PaidDisc Two: From the 2008 World Tour: (Song set)1.Got Me Under Pressure2.Waitin' for the Bus3.Jesus just left Chicago4.I'm Bad, I'm Nationwide5.Blue Jean Blues6.Heard it on the X7.Just Got Paid8.I Need You Tonight9.La Grange10.Hey Joe11.Tush.The approximate total running time for both disc is 154 minutes. This is a great double disc dvd of ZZ Top. You get to see them back in their younger days, with the 1980 concert. Then you get to see the more mature version of them on disc 2. This is the ultimate package deal for a ZZ Top Fan or any Rock Fan period.
summary: Most Comprehensive DVD Set Available for ZZ Top (2 Disc DVD) Includes a 1980 Concert in full + Performances from 2008 World Tour
Title: N/A

reviewText: A great look into the past and the present in the world that is ZZ Top. The first disc shows the group in earlier days, before the beards were too long. Great energy and fine showmanship even at this young age.The second disc shows the group more refined as they rock thru some of the songs now with such grace and ease. The energy is strong, but the presentation has been refined. Would recommend this set for any serious ZZ Top fan who not only enjoys their music, but also their always wonderful showmanship.
summary: Still rockin after all these years!

reviewText: THE ONLY REASON TO BUY THIS DOUBLE DVD IS FOR THE REMASTERED 1980 SHOW. I'VE OWNED THE BOOT OF THE 1980 SHOW FOR A LONG TIME AND AM GLAD THAT THE 1980 ROCKPALAST SHOW IS FINALLY OUT AND SOMEWHAT BETTER. THE SECOND DISC IS A TOTAL WASTE. IT'S LIKE WATCHING A AUDIENCE SHOT PILE OF CLIPS FROM DIFFERENT CONCERTS MIXED TOGETHER WITH A TRAVEL LOG OF WASTED CLIPS OF THE TOUR BUS AND WEARHOUSE SHOTS OF THE EQUIPMENT AND ANYTHING ELSE TO FILL UP THE DVD SO THEY CAN SELL IT AS A DOUBLE DVD SET. THE CONCERT RELEASED OF THE 2008 TEXAS CONCERT IS WHAT YOU WANT TO BUY.
summary: SUCKING THE MONEY OUT OF YOUR WALLET...

reviewText: Don't get me wrong, I am a big fan of zz top but was a little disappointed in this release.  The 1980 concert from germany is good but disc 2 I really did not like.  The camera jumping all over the place with weird shots and fading I just did not enjoy.  Not sure what zz top was thinking maybe they wanted to do something different from the live in texas yet it was a big turn off for me.  If you are a zz top fan be sure you see it then you can make a judgment.Peter J. Miller

reviewText: I bought the ZZ Top DVD of the 2008 show last year...and watched it exactly ONCE.  I briefly thought: is this the same band that is pictured on the Fandango album?  The second thought was: did they borrow their 2008 stage lighting and chrome from a regional beauty pagent stage?  Too much Glitter!  NOT the case here.  This 1980 show is the Real Deal.  This is the ZZ Top I grew up with during the seventies!  Unpretentious performance, adequate stage lighting...these guys rock from A to Z!! Incidentally, I found my copy at Wal-Mart, available as one disc  ( merely the 1980 concert ).  Technical note for Videophiles: even though it was a 1980 show, they were still using tube video cameras; hence the intermittent horizontal lines and "image smear" when a camera pulled away from stage lights.  Nice surprise with the stereo sound, though!
summary: The Real, Raw, Unedited, Unadorned Deal...

reviewText: The first disc is a great record of the band's early years.  So cool to see Billy and company without big shades on.  The second disc is a complete waste of time, though.  Frenetically edited and shot by a thousand caffeinated cameramen, it's to be avoided.  For a better look at more recent tours, try the Live From Texas DVD instead.  It rocks!
summary: Get the single disc version with just the Deguello show - you'll thank me

reviewText: The double DVD set Double Down Live (2008), features two live performances from veteran blues boogie rockers ZZ Top, at distinctly different points in their career.  Disc one labeled "Definitely Then...1980" is essentially a repackaged version of ZZ Top's "Live In Germany 1980" (1980) DVD, which features the "little ol' band from Texas" in an impressive 22 song, 92 minute performance recorded in Essen, Germany, for the TV program Rockplast.  Disc two is titled "Almost Now...2008", and features an eleven songs recorded live in 2007 and 2008, along with interview segments with guitar player Billy Gibbons, drummer Frank Beard, and bass player Dusty Hill, interspersed between songs.Disc One is a straightforward presentation that nicely captures the energy of band live.  Performing without matching costumes, customized instruments, sunglasses, and sparkling jewelry, the youthful Hill, Beard, and Gibbons appear quite animated, with a spry Gibbons often hopping and bobbing around the stage.  In contrast to the more flashy approach they would adopt later, ZZ Top rocks solidly, without much flash or pretense.  For those accustomed to seeing the band after their Eliminator "makeover", it's a bit of a shock to see them without their trademark shades, and in laid back attire.With uncoordinated outfits and instruments, Hill and Gibbons may not be making much of a fashion statement, as they let their music do the talking.  Although just a three piece, the band has a remarkably full sound live.  Billy Gibbons does a great job of deciding what to play, and impeccably balances playing rhythm and lead, with Dusty Hill stepping up at just the right times to help fill in the void.  Frank Beard has a really minimalist style of drumming that is quite remarkable.  He makes every hit count, and always under control, it seems that he could play forever.  Even at this point, these gentlemen know each other intimately, and ZZ Top operates like a well lubricated blues boogie rock machine.There may be a song or two that some fans would like to see included, but the performance probably includes most of the group's more well-known material, up to their latest album Deguello.  Things flow along quite smoothly up until the band returns to the stage for their first encore.  Upon resuming the stage, a video of the band as the "Lone Wolf Horns" playing saxophones, is displayed on a screen at the back of the stage.  While meant to enhance the performance, this ploy doesn't work very well.Camera coverage of the band is pretty good, and mostly on target, and the band seems less distant and more engaged than in some of their more recent performances.  The stage is well lighted, and image quality is very good for a 1980 show.  Gibbons' guitar sounds loud and full when playing rhythm, but at times there are some issues with the audio of some of the guitar solos.  Despite these problems, this performance provides a solid down and dirty look at the band, before they became a polished multi-platinum hit machine.  Rating: 5 Stars.Almost Now...2008 on Disc Two, features ZZ Top some 27 years later, with the band having long since adopted a more cool and coordinated look, which includes matching outfits, hats, shades, and accoutrements, and occasionally in the case of Hill and Gibbons, matching instruments.  This is not a pure concert video, as the live performances were recorded at many different shows, and there are interview segments and other miscellaneous footage inserted.It doesn't sound possible, but one person, James Burton Chamberlain, the director of Almost Now apparently shot all the footage himself, over the course of some 70 performances in 2008.  If that actually was the case, it probably wasn't the most efficient approach to shooting a concert film, but Chamberlain does a commendable job, featuring some unusual views, black and white footage, and more of a quick cutting style.Musically, ZZ Top is as solid as ever, but the eleven songs merely whet the appetite, rather than completely satisfy.  The selections include older concert staples like "Tush", "La Grange", "Waiting For the Bus/Jesus Just Left Chicago", and "Blue Jean Blues", but also includes the gem "I Need You Tonight" a great bluesy number that seldom appear on their setlist.  At times, the audio kind of sounds compressed and raspy, with some of the extreme highs and lows missing.  Clocking in at just over an hour, Almost Now...2008 is a fun time, but leaves you wanting much more.  Rating: 4 stars.Double Down Live is certainly a nice collection, but as Live In Germany is available separately, and may already have been purchased by many ZZ Top fans, a pertinent question may be, does Almost Now 2008 make this a set worth getting?  Superfans and completists may want Almost Now 2008 regardless, but for the casual fan looking for a great fairly recent performance from ZZ Top, their 2008 releaseLive from Texasmight be a better buy, and is also available in Bluray.  Live In Texas is a full length show, which has great sound and production values.  Together with Live In Germany, these two shows provide an excellent representation of ZZ Top, from two distinct eras in their history.
summary: have mercy!...ZZ Top rocks hard live
